pros: Wonderful student body. This is a place where you will really feel you are having an impact.
cons: Lots of changes in structure and management over the past two years.

review_title: Great place to work for students
pros: Staff is kind and welcoming
cons: Hours could interfere with those going to in person courses but management is more than willing to work around your schedule

pros: Flexible manager, cheap employee parking
cons: 2nd reorganization in 5 years makes reporting lines unclear too many vice presidents, deans, etc.

pros: flexible, good benefits, great management, advancement
cons: changing leadership, uncertain schedule term to term

pros: Overall the coworkers are great and hardworking.
cons: Too many institutional barriers for current employees. Anyone looking to advance with the college has to leave (usually for 2 years) then come back. HR also takes advantage of people in interim positions. It's quite common to "promote" folks into interim positions (up to 2 years) and then either move them back into their old job or pay them less than someone with the same qualifications coming from outside the organization.

pros: Relaxed work atmosphere, good people to work with, family friendly
cons: Union pay scale. Everyone in a job classification receives the same pay raise every year.

pros: Great working in the college
cons: Everything is great working in the college

pros: Yeah it's really the beans
cons: Great on all counts baby

review_title: Nice place to work-Rock Creek Campus Bookstore
pros:
Flexible when working with student schedules. 
Decent pay.
Good training.
Easy work.
cons:
Can be preferential to other workers but no more than anywhere else. 
Informal processes cause mild confusion at times.

job_title: Disability Services Counselor in Portland, OR
pros: Some of the best training and staff I have ever work with.
cons: PT schedules were given 3-4 days before each quarter so employment was unknown from quarter to quarter.

pros: Catered to my arts focus and was within maybe 700 feet of my living space. Easily accessible by bus system bike or foot. Campus store is decently stocked though premium prices. Teachers were wonderful and I enjoyed the campus. I had access to the gym and utilized it daily in addition to being close to the Ballet Classes, which I attended. I loved my summer ceramics course.
cons: I merely had personal difficulty meeting deadlines etc.

pros: Strong teaching union protects full and part time instructors
cons: Even with the good union, a strong caste system exists between administrators, full time instructors and part time instructors. Part time instructors can have their classes taken from them by full instructors and left with less pay. This routinely happens with enrollment dips. This is not the fault of the full timers but rather a direct result of the caste system the administration allows to exist.

job_title: Media Services Technician in Portland, OR
pros: learned new tech skills with lots of additional help on course work while taking full time class load
cons: none - i loved it there

pros: Flexible hours and work space
cons: A Low rate of $14/hr

review_title: Solid job in a learning environment
pros: Awesome staff, wonderful clients, autonomy, collaboration with co-workers, quality fitness equipment. Always plenty of clients. No selling of packages or supplements involved.
cons: Lack of benefits for part-time/contract staff.

pros: Can give it all at my job, then live my life after hours. Predictable pay scale available on HR's page.
cons: The "cycle" of education programs that are started, given a bit of time, then fading off is alive, but seemingly is being addressed with the college's campuses moving under one model.

pros: Lots of great people and trying to improve
cons: Going through seismic shifts in organization structure which is a little confusing and a little too much virtue signaling without any action.

review_title: PCC remains a terrific place to work
job_title: Faculty and Department Chair in Portland, OR
pros:
Freedom to manage my classes and department
Remote and hybrid modalities
Engaged colleagues
cons: Many of the faculty and staff complain too much

job_title: Adunct Faculty Member in Portland, OR
pros: Autonomy - until a student complains
cons: Students prioritized over part time faculty: you will be asked to tailor your assignments and due dates for as many as 20% of the students. You will be asked to update curriculum without pay. You will be on call 24/7 whereas your dept chair, full time faculty, and/or dean won’t answer most of your emails, and certainly not within 24 hrs. There is no mentorship outside of the voluntary, unpaid generic classes and workshops.

pros: Supportive management, good PTO, overall an accommodating employer.
cons: None I can think of.

pros: Good health insurance if you like Kaiser. Summers “off” (though initially unpaid.)
cons: No 401k matching. Extremely low pay for the work done (pandemic teaching college-level healthcare: online, on campus, in hospital, and public health.) Abusive and toxic culture in the department. Even for a pandemic, there’s no excuses to bully eachother, nor students, in 2020.

pros: Great mission to be excited about.
cons: Too numerous to list. Part timers are second-class citizens.

pros: accomodating for scheduling with course load.
cons: no advancement for an associates degree level.

pros:
Great pay provided by wonderful Union benefits.
Good Benefits: Health insurance, vacations, retirement.
Generally good coworkers, a few back stabbers but they’re everywhere.
Working in educational environment
working with students
cons:
Very political environment partially because of being a state agency. 
Rules may/may not apply to you depending on who your boss is.
Inconsistent management policies
Faculty valued more than administrators
Students are not as valued as "they" say

pros: Benefits and holidays work hours. Plenty to keep you busy. Some time too much work and not enough time in the day.
cons: Too much work, limited resources, tight timelines, much work is siloed with little input on processes or options to make changes.

review_title: review for PCC part time faculty position
pros: flexible hours as a part-time faculty teaching online courses
cons: senior leadership not very responsive to part-time faculty needs

job_title: Instructor of Humanities in Portland, OR
pros: Immediate enrollment into union – PCC FFAP. Large enough to thrive (offerings/enrollment). Large bureaucracy allows you to punt undesired elements above your pay grade. High degree of academic freedom.
cons: They break everything every year to find things to fix. Massive bureaucracy, and you can remain invisible for years. Low degree of agency or impact on the organization.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Beaverton, OR
pros: You can work while attend Pcc
cons: You pay for your own parking ticket

pros: normal student job before pandemic
cons: They let go almost all student job positions during pandemic

pros:
Puts students first.
Excellent opportunities for free continuing education.
Good pay and benefits.
Good union.
cons: None. I have been with them 6 years and always treated well.

pros: PERS, decent benefits, not micro-managed, can take classes along with working (college pays for equivalent of 8 credits per term at PCC only you pay fees and books), Union jobs
cons: Pay is low for metro area cost of living, raises aren’t based on performance just time served and Union contracts

pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Dealing with people that don't return calls or emails.

pros: It felt like a community to me. I loved it there. Wonderful benefits! Good salary.
cons: My only regret was that I couldn’t work remotely when I moved.

review_title: blend of technical and administrative experience needed for this role
job_title: Student Systems Support Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: work with multiple teams in both technical and administrative departments to develop solutions to streamline the admissions process experience for students applying to PCC
cons: institution is slow moving, change takes months to years

review_title: Overall good opportunity but no room for growth
job_title: Sustainability Communications and Marketing in Portland, OR
pros: Friendly people and many ways to support the sustainability program
cons: Manager felt controlling, every small project needed approval

pros: Great people to work with, great benefits
cons: Unless management, salaries are low.

pros: Follow federal, state, etc rules and regulations. Good benifits and retirement
cons: A lot of temp positions but some turn in to perm

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Very flexible with scheduling and easy to work with
cons: Nothing I can think of.

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Portland, OR
pros: Nice people, and easy going environment.
cons: The shifts can get incredibly boring.

pros: freedom to explore, amazing students, awesome teachers, learning on the job, major strides in inclusivity
cons: there's still a patriarchal bureaucracy underneath the good DIY vibes, and there's still a boy's club feeling even in the classroom, everyone except for salaried employees only hears about work a couple days before the term starts or even later.

pros: Clientele built in as PCC employees can use tuition benefit for Personal Training. Autonomy to make own schedule and programs. Amazing co-workers offering support and sharing best practices.
cons: Wish they had a better benefits plan for part time non-faculty

pros: Flexible and great networking potential
cons: The pay was not the highest. could have been better

review_title: Very flexible but adjunct salary not living wage
pros: Good students, kind and knowledgeable colleagues
cons: Adjuncting anywhere is not enough to live on.

job_title: Student Information Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Supervisors who take time to listen and work with you. Additional training and opportunities to advance. Great physical space and positive working environment. Willingness of employer to teach employees new skills and provide additional references to resources.
cons: Pay could be better. Interdepartmental communication needs improvement.

pros: Poepole are nice and fun! All of the people that I have met and worked with are professional, friendly, and passionate about helping students.
cons: There are multiple locations , so it's a bit difficult to get to know colleagues at different locations.

pros: Most if not all my co-workers really believed in PCC's mission of being as student focused as possible.
cons: Some people have been there too long

pros: Flexible schedule, a leadership program
cons: Time-consuming while being a student

review_title: proud of what PCC is and does
job_title: F-T CTE Faculty in Portland, OR
pros: Faculty and academic programs in CTE are far better than what you'd expect at a community college; I'd say better than most universities for a fraction the cost. Institution has the right values, such as equity, inclusion and diversifying the work force. Professional development opportunities abound.  Obvious care for students, who as a rule love the education they get. 'Real world' curricula leads to solid jobs for grads. Diversity within students, esp in age and experience, makes for rich classroom discussions. Union representation helps assure fairness in contracts. Benefits and PERS are decent. Sustainability is tantamount. A respected presence in the community with a strong vision for the future.
cons: Certain deans sleepwalk and are lousy communicators. Others know very little about some of the programs they oversee. Some faculty members check out and don't bother to stay current on teaching tactics or technology. Insufficient cross-departmental collaboration. Hiring processes take too long and seem overly skewed toward a sometimes-puzzling definition of diversity.

pros: A great environment with friendly staff and a focus on helping their students rather than pressuring sales. Because this is a job connected to a college, they are also great about working with changing availability each quarter. They never schedule you for hours you say you aren't available.
cons: Due to the nature of college bookstores, this is very much seasonal work. You will be able to get a lot of hours during breaks and the first and last couple weeks of a quarter, but the amount of staff required during the rest of the term is very minimal, so don't count on this job being able to give you a lot of hours during the entire quarter. Your hours may also be limited by Oregon laws for part time vs full time employees. Additionally, the Sylvania campus bookstore is much larger than the other campus bookstores, so fewer employees are needed at those campuses.

pros: management is supportive, great benefits and pay, good place to work if you want to teach or help people, they encourage professional development; strong union- job security (it is almost impossible to get fired if you have been around for a while)
cons: It is hard to move up within the college if you do not have previous management experience, there are more opportunities for lateral moves; it is so big, sometimes it can get a bit bureaucratic - for example, it takes for ever to hire someone because of the lengthy HR process; because people do not get fired, some "long timers" are not as motivated as new hires are; it may be hard to get in - many staff work as part-time and temporary before getting full -time position

pros: Great Campus', students eager to learn.
cons: Administration could care less about the part-time faculty (which is most of the faculty).  Those in my department who are/were full-time treated the part-time people like crap, like 2nd class, unworthy.  First, there are NO full-time openings so if you want to teach in Higher Ed you have to settle with part-time (adjunct). Second: most of us have 'real-world' experience where as most of the 'tenured' people are ancient and probably don't even qualify for their own jobs anymore.

pros: The student diversity is wonderful.  I've met staff at several different campuses and they seem to be as friendly as the staff at Rock Creek, where I worked for six months.  The math department is very organized and consistent with their expectations.
cons: The college is similar to other community colleges in that most of their instructors are only hired as part-time, so I had to work at 2 to 3 different colleges to make a living.   Also, PCC only sets up their schedules one term at a time, so each term you have to wait to know your schedule, and you don't know if you'll have 1, 2 or 3 classes or none.  Working at different colleges means you don't know from term to term what your income will be.

pros: Pleasant work culture; people are  friendly and relaxed.   Very good management but this depends on the department you work in.
cons: Not much monetary compensation or career advancement if you are part-time.  Takes a long time to get a full-time position here.  I've been here for about 6 years. No full-time openings in that entire time.  Work/life isn't so good as there is little or no mentoring of faculty when they start.  You'll be left to completely write all of the course material.  Also, not much feedback on how you are doing except for student evaluations that are vague and inaccurate.

review_title: Great co-workers and management - bad politics.
pros: Very good benefits and management within my department is stellar - they believe in the work we do and provide a great work environment for their employees.  Pay is about industry standard and the hours are normal.  General communication with managers and co-workers is spot on.
cons: The politics are ridiculous - part of the beast with the public sector.  That being said you don't have to play their games and they can't really do anything about it.

job_title: Student Resource Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Great benefits, healthy work and learning community, love my students and coworkers. A lot of freedom, space to grow and advancement. Start pay is low but over time, it will add up.
cons: They keep too many old lazy people around because they are afraid to fire them. I see so many unproductive staffs and manager taking advantage of the system. Parking is horrible at very campus and work space is very limited.

review_title: Great students, nice to get benefits
pros: Students are motivated and appreciative.  Rate of pay and benefits are good due to the union really fighting for us. Great training/classes offered (no pay, tho) to increase pedagogy, diversity, etc. that help with student interaction, curriculum development, student success, and pad the resume.
cons: Disconnect between management and part-time faculty (who teach 75% of classes).   Big disconnect between compensation for Part-time vs Full-time, with little -to-no-chance for full-time opportunities.

review_title: People wouldn't work here for 20 years if it was bad...
pros: Because it's an educational institution employees have access to tuition waivers and such.  There is a general encouragement and facilitation by management for staff learning and development.  Backgrounds of coworkers are varied and often educated and interesting.
cons: There is a glass ceiling between the "Classified" side and the "AP/Faculty" side.  A lot of the issues with any huge employer are there; A lot of internal bickering and strife, union disputes, funding issues, a feeling of getting lost in the machine.

review_title: Good job, Good pay, No movement
pros: Friendly staff, students are great. Job is challenging and interesting. If you have a FT benefited AP/Management/Classified position, the benefits are really nice. Free classes at PCC and tuition stipends at other schools!
cons: Adjunct, casual, and part time employees are treated as disposable and replaceable. This is, of course, part of a larger problem with adjunct positions in the US.  Another con is that being an adjunct instructor is kind of a dead end job here.

review_title: Good opportunity for students, new employees not so much
pros:
solid career opportunity if you can get in
union membership
competitive pay with other community colleges
people are great
helping students feels good
cons:
reluctant to take on new permanent employees
contract work does not lead to employment
can be overly political
cost cutting going on across departments

pros:
It's a big university system with 100,000ish students, so there are a lot of opportunities to take advantage of. 

The previous president (Dr. Jeremy Brown) was pretty bad. The interim president (Dr. Sylvia Kelley) seems like a good leader.
cons: Not a lot of accountability for employees - in particular, part-time, casual, adjunct, and temporary employees have poor conditions. Once you get benefits, they are good, but a lot of people don't have them and they also don't have job security.

job_title: Computer Applications Instructor in Portland, OR
pros:
I work with people who care about students.
As a Department (Computer Applications & Office Systems), we are working hard to align our programs and content to the needs and goals of business professionals.
Quality of instruction and care for students, in general, is improving.
cons:
Large institution issues still exist.
Educational organizations don't function at the same level of demands and expectation as the business world (partially related to Union environment)

review_title: Employer provides good support, well definded policies
pros: My job allows me to structure my work that way I want to do it, as long as I get the job done. Managers are easy going. I feel like a valued member of the staff. Compensation and benefits are excellent.
cons: So far, I haven't found any cons to working for Portland Community College

review_title: PCC is an amazing employer in terms of Professional Dev.
pros: I love the work we do to support the educational and professional needs of the community through innovative programs to support high quality academics while holding in mind our mission to increase diversity, equity, and inclusion in all that we do from academic coursework to enrollment processes to our faculty/ staff, and our increased student access to college credentials.
cons: Sometimes not enough $$ to go around.  Many positions are limited duration depending upon funding.

pros: Working on campus is convenient.  There are perks balanced by disadvantages.  It is a safe space to develop skills around working with the public
cons: "Student Leadership" is a predefined concept into which employees are cast.  It's difficult to lead in a straight narrow hallway lined by locked doors.

pros: There is a fair amount of independence in your job task, for it is pretty straightforward Job.
cons: Way too {Political}... Too many brown-nosing Supervisors that don't have a clue on how to do their Job. Look to how they mismanaged the Construction of a the new Roof at Willow Creek( Oregonlive Article ), Good-old boy hiring practices: that is why the Public Safety has mostly retired Cops going after their double-dipping pension.

pros: It's rewarding to work somewhere that plays such a positive role in the community and in students' lives. Union representation protects employees and opportunities for growth. Lots of diversity among colleagues in terms of their backgrounds and professional experience, so there are lots of people to learn from.
cons: Super bureaucratic. Everything moves slowly. So many employees that it can be easy to get lost in the shuffle, so everyone has to be a really good self-advocate.

pros: Great place to work in because of the collaborative environment offering stimulating access too other advisors, PCC staff and administrators. Clients are especially satisfying to work for. They are interesting, self starters, entrepreneurial and are paying attention.
cons: SBDC is now housed in the Climb Center which does not have windows that open nor parking for employees.

job_title: Print Center Operations Coordinator in Portland, OR
pros: The faculty and staff are very dedicated to student success.  It's a stimulating and diverse work environment.
cons: There are so many campuses and divisions that each tends to create it's own culture, environment, and bureaucracy that can sometimes be inefficient.

pros: There mission statement, Portland Community College supports student success by delivering access to quality education while advancing economic development and promoting sustainability in a collaborative culture of diversity, equity and inclusion. The staff and faculty are all excellent people to be around and work with. They take there time to help  you and teach you  what you need. They have excellent benefits.
cons: It's hard to get full time.

pros: Amazing atmosphere to learn new things.
cons: No health care provided for part time administrative employees. Upper management needs to loosen their reigns of control when it comes to their coworkers and not treat them like work mules. Hard to work up the ladder.

review_title: Politics at work but otherwise good
pros: wide variety of positions, ability to change departments; good benefits; reasonable salaries for most positions. Working conditions are standard for office positions.
cons: Politics are played. Many positions are filled by who you know, now what you know. Running afoul of the union can cause problems. Expansion and resources are decided for political benefit, not necessarily the benefit of students.

pros: Excellent Union, wonderful colleagues, and delightful student who will change the world in substantive ways!
cons: It seems unfair that at anytime, a FT Instructor can 'bump a PT Instructor. And yet 76% of all courses taught @ PCC, are taught by PT Instructors! And, if I don't find another position at PCC within 4 terms, I am no longer employed by the college.

pros: Lots of great and inspiring stories to draw from. The overall purpose of the institution is a wonderful thing.
cons: Too many meetings to accomplish anything. Projects sometimes aren't able to be completed within a year due to the endless amount of input each sector of the institution. Things move slow and change is looked upon with fear and suspicion.

pros: Faculty across all disciplines is committed to helping students succeed. Also, in my experience, PCC is a very friendly, collegial place to work.
cons: Depending on the department, part-timers and adjunct faculty are often overworked and undervalued. Because hiring committees are not supposed to take prior work into consideration when selecting candidates for open positions, it's very difficult for part-timers to make the jump to full-time status.

pros: Lots of great medical and insurance benefits.  Great people to work with.  Lots of diversity.
cons: PCC is an organization that has to operate according to budgets. It is more cost effective to hire many part-time instructors with limited experience than pay professional instructors at the top of the salary range.  That often affects the quality of education and the morale of students and faculty.

job_title: Faculty Department Chair in Portland, OR
pros: PCC has a wonderful and professional working environment. People become like family once you work there for a while. Very friendly. Great benefits.
cons: Budget cuts every so often creates a bit of low morale among staff.

pros: PCC does provide decent benefits and there are many people who are compassionate, caring, and dedicated to student success.
cons: The faculty and staff are not very diverse (especially higher up), and the work environment tends to be insular--meaning, it can be difficult to get a job, if you haven't worked for them in one capacity or another.

review_title: PTK President at PPC Cascade; YES!
pros:
-Paid position when other community colleges consider my position an unpaid. 
-Develop many great friendships with the students, advisors, and staff. 
-Leadership and teamwork hands-on experience. 
-Get invited to many life-changing conferences to meet other PTK students and other opportunities. 
-Hands-on experience for Project/Event Management. 
-Highly recommend for those aiming for college scholarships!
cons: -Demanding physically and emotionally.

review_title: Lots of Changes Makes the Future Unclear
pros: Many positions are flexible allowing for work-life balance and opportunities to take courses for professional development; students are incredible to work with
cons: Lots of upper level and executive management changes in personnel and as such the direction and future of the institution seems unclear

pros:
Has well defined expectations of employment.
Good Benefits and opportunity for growth.
Good reputation in community.
People are collaborative in shared mission.
cons:
Administration currently facing big changes.
Message and mission can get diluted diverted in such a large place.

pros: People in general really care about student success at PCC, which makes for a good group of coworkers.
cons: Employment term-to-term isn't stable for many. Granted, I was a casual employee, but I knew instructors who had been there for years and still were getting their hours cut , had their jobs reclassified to something without benefits, etc.

review_title: He tries but there's too much inertia.
job_title: Technical Specialist II in Portland, OR
pros: Public service and job security.
cons: Politics and "siloing" of resources can be overwhelming. The institution loves to always take "low bid" and usually then finds the product/service does not meet needs.

pros: adjunct professors are eligible for health insurance after teaching for one year.
cons: there is no guarantee that you will have consistent teaching assignments due to changes in enrollment and numbers of class sections offered from term to term. no job security. no retirement. very little support.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in North Portland, OR
pros: Really fine people.    Excellent contract for adjunct instructors with the college putting 6% of their own $$$ into state retirement.     When I left, I was making about $80/classroom hour=50 minutes
cons: Instructors must pay to park on campus lots

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Portland, OR
pros:
Do homework during shift.
Easy work, babysit the printers and help students with internet, MS office, and other simple issues.
Flexible hours.
cons:
Easiest job ever, other co-workers manage to mess up and break rules. (No eating, no headphones)
May be difficult to get the max of 20 hours a week.

job_title: Financial Aid Technician II in Portland, OR
pros: Great environment, friendly co-workers, easy job, one of the best benefits in state
cons: Job is too easy after a while, not feeling challenged enough, hard to grow within the company, too many regulations to abide by.

pros: Working at PCC gives you a flexible schedule and opportunities to work with a diverse population of students.
cons: Sometimes knowing how to set appropriate boundaries  an be difficult.also you have to be careful to not express your opinion so everyone feels safe and welcome to share theirs.

pros: slower pace, people friendly, plenty of interactions with people, especially with students.  Can make a difference in the lives of students.
cons: Not so dynamic, somewhat inefficient

pros: They care about their students and their employees.
cons: lack of transparency from leadership. A lot of red tape or just confusion about who is in charge of certain issues.

job_title: Computing Technology Specialist II in Portland, OR
pros: Good benefits and retirement system.
cons: Senior management and executive administration should review that they are to be working as servants of the Public's welfare .

review_title: Great Place to Work, Hard to move around
job_title: Student Help Desk Technician in Portland, OR
pros:
Good Union
Good Benefits
Free Tuition
Wonderful spaces
Clean
Good parking options for staff
cons:
Temporary Jobs. They will go away, and there is no way to just be placed in the job either.
HR doesn't seem to work with Departments to keep wanted employees.

job_title: Instructional Support Tech IV in Portland, OR
pros: The experience you gain from working with the future and the past people. I enjoyed the open view points.
cons: Sometimes the right hand has no clue what the left is doing. but, they are a good company to work for.

review_title: For a large, public institution, it is a very pleasant place to work.
pros:
Direct impact on other peoples lives
Important part of the community
Excellent benefits
Important mission
cons:
Large, bureaucratic instition
Publicly funded (sometimes positive, sometimes negative)
Very political and politically correct

pros:
• Good Wages
• Fair hiring practices 
• Academic community 
• Multiple campuses/locations in the    Portland area 
• Students are a fun population to work with
cons: No cons in my experience.

pros: the people are very nice to work with, and the hours are flexible because they accommodate for your school schedule
cons: it is a very needy environment and it takes a lot of patience. pay isn't good

pros: PCC’s math department is very inclusive and welcoming. The best colleagues and open to new and improving practices.
cons: It is hard to find parking

pros: Professional and well known organization. Opportunity to grow. Gaining a lot of experience.
cons: No challenges. Great place to work in. Need to improve constantly to to catch up with latest curriculums.

pros: Great opportunity to help students succeed! The Student Learning Center has a great leadership team the works well together provide exceptional support to students.
cons: All campus departments are not the same.

pros: A lot of autonomy and dynamic faculty which maintain a positive and professional atmosphere.
cons: Really poor management at top levels.

pros: Flexible schedule, little oversight, ability to work mostly independently.
cons: Little oversight, little opportunity go gain full-time employment (and, thus, benefits)

pros: lots of one on one with professors
cons: limited choices for scheduling, makes it difficult to find classes when convienient.

review_title: Portland Community College cares about it's employees
pros: Consistent, timely raises. Flexible schedule. Tuition discounts. Excellent environment.
cons: I really can't provide one.

pros: The team was laid back and open to suggestions about projects and workflow. Great  environment.
cons: The office is deep in the west side suburbs of Portland.

pros: Very open to growth, understanding, and development
cons: Things take time to happen

job_title: Instructor, Computer Applications in Portland, OR
pros: Inclusive and innovative educational institution that is always putting the interests and needs of its staff and students first.
cons: No cons to report here.

pros: Great options for students who have schedules that are out of the norm, good class choices and good programs for transferring.
cons: Campuses are too spread out.

pros:
+Super understanding of class schedule and class needs.
+Flexible scheduling
+Hardly any weekend work
+Good pay for college students
+Provide a lot of training
cons: +Office settings can be a bit drab

job_title: Computer Technology Specialist in Portland, OR
pros: Benefits and work environment
cons: No Job performance review so there are some that do nothing and get paid.

pros: This is very Student friendly
cons: Work can be distracting for school

pros: Staff is very supportive and nice.
cons: Hard to become permanent full time employee.

job_title: Japanese Language Instructor in Portland, OR
pros: Classroom immersion style of instruction; students are generally motivated to learn
cons: As a part-time instructor, work hours/classes are term to term uncertain

pros: If you can be classified as a regular employee, you will receive free tuition for a limited number of credits per term.
cons: The main goal is to keep many of the employees at the lowest salary possible.

review_title: A very good place to work
pros: People are super friendly and caring. No stress at work
cons: I don't think there is any cons.

pros: Very Good Staff. High Quality Education. Medium sized student class sizes.
cons: Better parking for students and staff.

pros:
Understanding managers
Great benefits
Helping students
Great community
cons:
Hard to get support
A lot of work to be done, not much appreciation

pros: Local organization dedicated to the betterment of the community via education.
cons: Not many 10 year contracts offered

pros: Pay is great. PERS is great.
cons: None. I cannot think of one.

pros: Peers and students make the job worth doing.
cons: Pay is low, and good luck landing full time employment.

pros: Excellent educational organization. Professional and lots of opportunities to learn more.
cons: part time jobs only and few hours.

review_title: Portland Community College is  Great place to work.
job_title: Instructor, Computer Science in Portland, OR
